title: How to See Every File On Your Computer in CMD (Command Prompt)

steps.title: Open Command Prompt as an administrator.
steps.content: Open Command Prompt as an administrator. Type "Command Prompt" in your Start menu and right-click the "Command Prompt" result to open another menu. Select Run as administrator .

steps.title: Navigate to the drive where you want to list all the files.
steps.content: Navigate to the drive where you want to list all the files. Use the cd command to enter the root of your main drive. For example, if you want to list every file on your C drive, type cd C:\ and press Enter .

steps.title: Type dir /s and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type dir /s and press ↵ Enter . This will show you every file on the drive in the Command Prompt window. You can also use additional parameters with the dir command to change what you see. Some popular parameters and their uses are: dir /s /a:[attributes] displays files with specified attributes. For example, dir /s /a:h lists hidden files, and dir /s /a:d shows directories. [1] X Research source dir /s /b shows the files in bare format (no headers or summary). dir /s /o:[order] specifies the order to display the files. dir /s /o:n displays files in alphabetical order. dir /s /o:d displays files oldest to newest. dir /s /o:s sorts files smallest to largest. dir /s /o:-s sorts files largest to smallest. Enter dir /s /a:hs /q C:\Windows > myfile.txt to send the results to a text file instead of viewing them in the Command Prompt window. You can open that file with Notepad to read it, or you can type type myfile.txt . [2] X Research source
